sentence.Network_en: I am sick of having to truckle to my superiors.

sentence.Network_en: Don't truckle under to unreasonable demands.
I hate to truckle to my superiors.

derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English (denoting a wheel or pulley): from Anglo-Norman French trocle, from Latin trochlea 'sheaf of a pulley'. The current sense dates from the early 19th cent. and was originally dialect
mid 17th cent.: figuratively, from truckle bed; an earlier use of the verb was in the sense sleep in a truckle bed

means.word_mean: 1. a low bed to be slid under a higher bed
2. try to gain favor by cringing or flattering;

sentences.sentence: "He is always kowtowing to his boss"

auth_sentence.content: He was young and cocksure and he wouldn't truckle.

auth_sentence.content: All my life I've had to truckle to the idea that you knew everything.
